Scheme 1 Proposed reaction routes for the STA reaction over the tandem catalysts. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of the tandem catalysts. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 SEM images of the typical catalysts: (a) HZ27, (b) FeMnK/SiO2, (c) FeMnK/SiO2-HZ27, (d) FeMnK/SiO2-HZ80. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 EDS analysis of FeMnK/SiO2-HZ27 (a) and FeMnK/SiO2-HZ80 (b). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 H2-TPR profiles of the tandem catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XRD patterns of the fresh (A) and spent (B) tandem catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 NH3-TPD profiles of the catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Py-IR spectra (A) and B/L ratio (B) of the tandem catalysts. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Effect of reaction temperature on (A) CO conversion and hydrocarbon distribution and (B) Selectivity in C5 + hydrocarbons. Reaction conditions: P = 2.0 MPa, GHSV = 6000 h−1, TOS = 10 h. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Effect of GHSV on (A) CO conversion and hydrocarbon distribution and (B) Selectivity in C5 + hydrocarbons. Reaction conditions: T = 320 °C, P = 2.0 MPa, TOS = 10 h. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Effect of reaction pressure on (A) CO conversion and hydrocarbon distribution and (B) Selectivity in C5 + hydrocarbons. Reaction conditions: T = 320 °C, GHSV = 4000 h−1, TOS = 10 h. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Effect of the proximity of the two catalysts. (A) CO conversion and hydrocarbon distribution over different combinations of FeMnK/SiO2 and HZSM-5 catalysts. TOS = 30 h. (B) The product distribution over powder-mixing. (C) The stability of the tandem catalyst with powder-mixing. Reaction conditions: T = 320 °C, GHSV = 4000 h−1, P = 2.0 MPa. Fig. 11 Table 1 Textural properties of the various catalysts. Graphical abstract Direct synthesis of aromatics from syngas was studied by a tandem catalyst of FeMnK/SiO2 with HZSM-5. A decrease in SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of HZSM-5 decreased the crystal sizes of the tandem catalyst, restraining the reduction of iron oxides. Especially, The HZSM-5 with lower SiO2/Al2O3 ratio promoted the formation of strong Brönsted acid sites (BAS). There existed a linear relationship between the BAS amount and aromatics selectivity. Increasing reaction temperature facilitated the formation of aromatics while the increase in both gas space velocity (GHSV) and pressure restrained the selectivity of aromatics. The tandem catalyst of FeMnK/SiO2 with HZSM-5 presented excellent STA performances of 83.80% CO conversion and 57.17% aromatics selectivity under optimizing reaction conditions of 320 °C, 2.0 MPa and 4000 h−1. This work indicated that a combination of Fe-Mn based catalyst with HZSM-5 could promote the direct conversion of syngas to aromatic hydrocarbons. Keywords Syngas to aromatics FeMnK/SiO2-HZSM-5 Acid sites Reaction conditions Fischer-Tropsch synthesis 1 Introduction Aromatics used as the important basic material for synthesizing fibers, resins, rubbers and fine chemicals in the polymer industry, is mainly produced by petroleum cracking. [1–3] With growing shortage of petroleum resource and economy development, alternative modes of producing aromatics are developed, in which the conversion of syngas derived from biomass, coal or natural gas into aromatic hydrocarbons has attracted more and more attention. [4–6] Two-step processes including syngas to methanol (STM) and methanol to aromatics (MTA) are firstly developed, which are highly energy consumption and cost. Subsequently, combining two processes into one, i.e., direct conversion of syngas into aromatics (STA), undergoes rapid development due to its advantage in the operation cost and process energy consumption. Two routes for direct conversion of syngas to aromatics are developed in recent years. One is syngas to aromatics via methanol intermediate (methanol synthesis route), and another is syngas to aromatics via light olefins intermediate (Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) route). The Cu-Zn based catalyst is widely used to transform syngas to methanol (<300 °C), and the zeolite catalyst is used to convert methanol to aromatics (>400 °C). [3,7–11] The mismatch of operating temperature for the Cu-Zn based catalyst and zeolite decreases obviously the STA performances. Cheng et al. [12] designed a powerful bi-functional catalyst of Zn-ZrO2/H-ZSM-5 for direct conversion of syngas into aromatics, which presented 80% selectivity of aromatics at CO conversion of 20%. The results of Chang et al. [13] indicated that the Zn-Cr/HZSM-5 catalyst displayed 70% aromatics selectivity. However, the operating conditions are severe and reaction activity is low for the Zn-Cr high-temperature methanol synthesis catalysts. On the other hand, many efforts have been devoted to developing the FTS route for direct conversion of syngas to aromatics. [14,15] Compared to other Fischer-Tropsch synthesis catalysts (including Ni, Ru and Co), the Fe-based catalyst is suited for lower H2/CO ratio syngas derived from coal or biomass, due to its higher water-gas shift activity and favorable engineering characteristics. Especially, the operating temperature of Fe-based FTS catalysts is matched to olefins aromatization temperature of zeolite catalysts. Chang et al. [13] reported firstly the Fe-based FTS catalyst with zeolite for converting syngas directly into aromatics. Yan et al. [16] prepared the Pd-modified Fe/HZSM-5 catalyst for syngas to aromatics, and found that the aromatics selectivity in C5 + hydrocarbons ranged from 29 to 45% with changing reaction conditions. The results of Guan et al. [4] indicated that the Fe-MnO/GaZSM-5 catalyst presented 40% aromatics selectivity, whereas deactivated rapidly with time on stream. All of these catalysts were not presented high catalytic activity and high aromatics selectivity. Recently, Ma et al. [17] designed a Na-Zn-Fe5C2 catalyst, which displayed high CO conversion and high alkenes selectivity. They combined the Na-Zn-Fe5C2 catalyst with hierarchical HZSM-5, which presented 51% aromatics selectivity under the stable state with over 85% CO conversion. [18] The coupling method of syngas to olefins and olefins to aromatics results in a significant breakthrough in hydrocarbons products derived from Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, which provides a promising route for syngas converting directly to aromatics. Manganese has been widely used as an efficient promoter to modify the electronic characteristics of iron-based FTS catalysts, which facilitates the formation of C2-4 olefins [19] or C5 + olefins [20] by enhancing CO and inhibiting H2 chemisorption. In our previous work, a Fe-Mn based catalyst (Fe-Mn-K/SiO2) was reported to present high activity and high alkenes selectivity (80% CO conversion and 60% olefins selectivity) with long-time stable state. [21] Coupling the FeMnK/SiO2 catalyst with HZSM-5 would be an efficient method for promoting the direct conversion of syngas into aromatics. Here, a tandem catalyst of FeMnK/SiO2 with HZSM-5 for syngas to aromatics were constructed. The effects of acid sites in HZSM-5, operating conditions and proximity of the two catalysts on the STA performances were studied. The catalysts were characterized by N2 physisorption, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) and pyridine adsorption infrared spectroscopy (Py-IR). The characterization results were discussed, and correlated with the catalytic performances in details. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The FeMnK/SiO2 FTS catalyst was prepared by a co-precipitation method. Typically, an appropriate amount of ferric nitrate and manganese nitrate were dissolved in deionized water together to form a mixed salt solution. An aqueous solution of ammonia and the mixed salt solution were added to a flask dropwise under stirring at 70 °C and pH = 9.0 ± 0.1. After aging for 3 h, the precipitate was filtered and washed with deionized water for three times. Potassium nitrate and silica sol were added to the filter cake, and the mixture was then re-slurried. After rotary evaporation at 80 °C, the product was dried at 120 °C overnight and calcined at 500 °C for 5 h. Finally, the sample was pressed and crushed. The obtained catalyst was composed of 100 Fe/(10, 50) Mn/5 K/20 SiO2 in molar ratio. Commercial HZSM-5 with different SiO2/Al2O3 ratios (SiO2/Al2O3 ratio = 27, 38, 50, and 80) were purchased from Nankai University catalyst company. These zeolites were denoted as HZx, where x was the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio. Before used, these zeolites were calcined in static air at 540 °C for 6 h. The FeMnK/SiO2-HZSM-5 catalyst was typically prepared by powder-mixing unless otherwise noted. Typically, FeMnK/SiO2 was mixed with HZSM-5 (the mass ratio of two components = 1:1) in an agate mortar for 15 min, and then the tandem catalyst was pressed and crushed. The obtained catalysts were denoted as FeMnK/SiO2-HZx. The molar ratio of Fe/Mn used in FeMnK/SiO2-HZx was 100/10. For the preparation of FeMnK/SiO2-HZSM-5 with granule-mixing, FeMnK/SiO2 and HZSM-5 were pressed and crushed, respectively. Then, the granules of two catalysts were mixed together by shaking in a vessel. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Textural properties of the catalyst samples were measured by N2 physisorption at −196 °C using a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 instruments. The samples were degassed under vacuum at 120 °C for 6 h prior to measurement. The specific surface area of the catalysts was calculated by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method and the pore size distribution was analyzed by Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained on a QUANTA F250 scanning electron microscope to characterize the surface morphology of the tandem catalysts. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) was performed on a GENESIS EDX detector. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a PANalytical X’Pert Pro diffractometer over the 2θ range of 5°–80°. H2-TPR measurements were performed in a quartz tube equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The samples were pretreated with high purity N2 at 150 °C and a flow rate of 30 mL/min for 1.5 h to remove water and other contaminants. The samples were cooled down to room temperature, and then 5% H2/N2 was introduced into the system at a flow rate of 30 mL/min. The TCD signal and sample temperature were recorded while the temperature being ramped to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min (held at 800 °C for 30 min). The acid sites on the catalyst was determined by pyridine adsorption infrared spectroscopy (Py-IR). The measurements were performed on a Frontier FT-IR Spectrometer. The acid amount and strength of the catalysts were measured by NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD). The sample (100 mg) was pretreated with high purity N2 at a flow rate of 30 mL/min and 500 °C for 1 h, and then cooled to 100 °C. Saturated adsorption of NH3 on the sample was achieved by introducing 5% NH3/N2 into the system at a flow rate of 30 mL/min for 1.5 h. The sample tube was then purged with high purity N2 to remove the physically adsorbed NH3 until the baseline was stable, and then NH3-TPD was performed in high purity N2 at a flow rate of 30 mL/min by raising the temperature to 800 °C with a ramp of 10 °C/min. The desorbed NH3 during the heating process was detected by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 2.3 Catalytic experiments The catalytic tests were conducted in a fixed-bed, stainless flow microreactor. Typically, 1 g of catalyst was loaded into the reactor. The catalyst was reduced in H2 atmosphere at 350 °C, 0.1 MPa and 4000 h−1 for 10 h. After on-line activation described above and cooling to 200 °C, syngas (H2 (47.5%)/CO (47.5%)/N2 (5%), vol) was introduced into the reactor, followed by a rise of reaction temperature with a rate of 1 °C/min. The reaction was carried out at the desired temperature, gas space velocity and pressure. The operation conditions for the tandem catalysts were as follows: temperature of 280–340 °C, GHSV of 2000–6000 h−1 and pressure of 1.0–4.0 MPa. Reaction products were separated by a hot trap (kept at 50 °C) and a cold trap (kept at 1 °C). Gaseous products were detected online by a gas chromatograph (FULI GC 97) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID). Porapak Q and 5A MolSieve packed column were connected to TCD, while RB-PLOT Al2O3 capillary column was connected to FID. Liquid products were detected on a gas chromatograph (FULI GC 97) with a FID using RB-5 capillary column. CO conversion and product selectivity were calculated on a carbon-atom basis. The carbon balance calculated in each test was between 94% and 102%. CO conversion was calculated by Eq. (1): (1) C O c o n v e r s i o n = C O i n − C O o u t C O i n × 100 % where CO in and CO out represent mole of CO at the inlet and outlet, respectively. CO2 selectivity was calculated by Eq. (2): (2) C O 2 s e l e c t i v i t y = C O 2 o u t C O i n − C O 2 o u t × 100 % where CO2out refers to mole of CO2 at the outlet. The selectivity of individual hydrocarbon in total hydrocarbons was calculated by Eq. (3): (3) C i H m s e l e c t i v i t y = i × C i H m o u t C O i n − C O o u t − C O 2 o u t × 100 % where CiHmout and i mean mole of individual hydrocarbon at the outlet and carbon number of a hydrocarbon molecule, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural properties and XRD results Textual properties of the tandem catalysts were shown in Fig. 1 and Table 1 . From Fig. 1 it could be found that HZSM-5 had a typical microporous structure, whereas FeMnK/SiO2 presented a typical mesoporous structure according to the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms. After physical mixing of FeMnK/SiO2 with HZSM-5, the tandem catalyst displayed the typical mesoporous structures, indicating that the coupling of FeMnK/SiO2 and HZSM-5 did not change pore structures of the single catalyst. Besides, BET surface area of FeMnK/SiO2 was 165.3 m2/g, which increased sharply after mixing with HZSM-5 (shown in Table 1), validating that pore structures of both the FeMnK/SiO2 and HZSM-5 were not blocked after physical mixing. Accompanied with the decrease in SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of HZSM-5, BET surface area of the tandem catalysts presented an increasing trend, which implied that a decrease in SiO2/Al2O3 ratio resulted possibly in the decrease of morphologies and crystal sizes of HZSM-5, increasing BET surface area of the tandem catalysts. SEM images of the various catalysts were shown in Fig. 2 . EDX analysis results (as shown in Fig. 3 ) displayed that all of Fe, Mn, K, O, Si and Al elements were presented in the particles of the tandem catalysts, indicating that FeMnK/SiO2 and HZSM-5 were well mixed together. It was apparent that crystal sizes of FeMnK/SiO2-HZ27 were smaller than that of FeMnK/SiO2-HZ80, which suggested that lower SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of HZSM-5 decreased crystal sizes of the tandem catalysts. This is consistent with the BET results. Reduction behavior of the tandem catalysts was characterized by H2-TPR. As shown in Fig. 4 , the HZSM-5 zeolite (HZ27) had no reduction peaks, whereas FeMnK/SiO2 displayed two obvious reduction peaks in the region of 450 °C and 750 °C, which were contributed to the reduction of Fe2O3 to FeO and FeO to α-Fe, respectively. [22,23] After physical mixing of both the catalysts, the reduction peaks shifted towards lower temperature, implying that the coupling of FeMnK/SiO2 with HZSM-5 facilitated the adsorption of H2 species on the tandem catalyst, promoting the reduction of iron oxides. In addition, reduction temperature of iron oxides shifted further towards lower temperature with an increase in SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of HZSM-5. Both the BET and SEM results mentioned above indicated that decreasing SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of HZSM-5 resulted in the decrease of crystal sizes of the tandem catalysts, which restrained generally the reduction of the catalyst particles. Therefore, an increase in SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of HZSM-5 promoted the reduction of iron oxides in the tandem catalysts. The XRD patterns of fresh and spent tandem catalysts were shown in Fig. 5 . The HZSM-5 sample (Fig. 5A) exhibited typical diffraction peaks of the MFI topology structure (JCPDS number 44-0003). FeMnK/SiO2 presented two weak broad diffraction peaks around 35° and 64°, which are attributed to the Fe2O3 phase (JCPDS number 73-2234). The appearance of weak broad diffraction peaks of Fe2O3 implied that iron oxides were well dispersed on the catalyst. [24,25] There was no observation of manganese and potassium species for FeMnK/SiO2 in the XRD patterns due to the addition of few amounts of the promoters. For the tandem catalysts, there were the typical diffraction peaks of MFI topology structure and Fe2O3 phase, which further certified that the combination of FeMnK/SiO2 and HZSM-5 did not destroy pore structures of the single catalyst. In addition, it could be found that the intensity of diffraction peaks of the tandem catalysts presented a slightly decreasing trend with decreasing SiO2/Al2O3 ratio in HZSM-5, indicating that the decrease of SiO2/Al2O3 ratio in HZSM-5 resulted in the decrease of crystallinity and particle size of the tandem catalysts, which is consistent with the results mentioned above. After reaction, the diffraction peaks of MFI topology structure did not destroy (shown in Fig. 5B), implying that the MFI structure of HZSM-5 remained unchanged with time on stream during the STA process. In addition, there were the appearance of diffraction peaks of Fe3O4 and iron carbides (FexC) species for the spent tandem catalysts, suggesting that the Fe2O3 phase was converted to Fe3O4 and FexC species in the STA reaction. The FexC species appeared were considered to the active sites for FTS reaction. [26–31] 3.2 Acidic properties The strength of acid sites in the tandem catalysts was characterized by NH3-TPD. As shown in Fig. 6 , HZ27 displayed two broad desorption peaks in the region of 250 °C and 650 °C, which were corresponded to the weak and strong acid sites, respectively. [11,32–34] Due to no desorption peaks of NH3 species on FeMnK/SiO2, the NH3 desorption peaks on the tandem catalysts could be stemmed from the weak and strong acid sites of HZSM-5. After combining HZ27 with FeMnK/SiO2, the area of NH3 desorption peaks decreased obviously. Besides, the desorption peak shifted to a higher temperature. It is possible that the coupling of FeMnK/SiO2 with HZSM-5 enhances the adsorption ability of acid sites, shifting the desorption peaks of NH3 species towards higher temperature. In addition, the peak area of weak and strong acid sites in the tandem catalysts presented an increasing trend with a decrease of SiO2/Al2O3 ratio, which indicated that lower SiO2/Al2O3 ratio in HZSM-5 strengthened the amounts of weak and strong acid sites. Acidic properties of the tandem catalysts were further characterized by Py-IR spectra, as presented in Fig. 7 . Typically, the band at approximately 1545 cm−1 in the Py-IR spectra was related to the Brönsted acid sites formed by the framework Al species, while the band at around 1454 cm−1 was related to the Lewis acid sites formed by the extra-framework Al species. [35] From Fig. 7A it could be found that the intensity of Brönsted acid sites increased gradually with a decrease of SiO2/Al2O3 ratio in HZSM-5, suggesting that decreasing SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of HZSM-5 facilitated the increase of Brönsted acid sites amounts, which is consistent with the previous report. [12] The ratio of Brönsted acid sites to that of Lewis acid sites (B/L ratio) was shown in Fig. 7B, which showed an increasing trend with a decrease of SiO2/Al2O3 ratio in HZSM-5. According to the Py-IR spectra and NH3-TPD results mentioned above, it suggests that changing the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of HZSM-5 could adjust the amounts of Brönsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites. The amounts of Brönsted acid sites might be improved by decreasing the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of HZSM-5. 3.3 STA catalytic performances STA performances of the tandem catalysts were measured under reaction conditions of 300 °C, 2.0 MPa, 6000 h−1, H2/CO = 1 and TOS = 30 h. As shown in Table 2 , the FeMnK/SiO2 catalyst (the molar ratio of Fe/Mn is 10) presented the typical Fischer-Tropsch synthesis performances of 82.47% CO conversion with the selectivities of 17.42% CH4, 29.73% C2-4 and 52.84% C5 + hydrocarbons. With the increasing of Mn content in FeMnK/SiO2, the selectivity of CH4 decreased, whereas that of olefins increased. The CH4 selectivity decreased from 17.42% of FeMnK/SiO2 (100Fe/10Mn) to 8.26% of FeMnK/SiO2 (100Fe/50Mn), while the selectivity of olefins increased from 48.25% to 67.50%, indicating that the adding of Mn promoter in the FeMnK/SiO2 catalyst promoted the formation of olefins and suppressed the production of CH4, which is consistent with the results of Zhang et al. [20]. In addition, a high CO2 selectivity (46.75%) was observed for FeMnK/SiO2 (100Fe/10Mn) (Table 2), which could be attributed to a lower H2/CO ratio (the ratio of H2/CO is 1.0) in the present study, leading to a higher CO2 selectivity [36]. Furthermore, a higher reaction temperature (300 °C) facilitated the formation of carbon dioxide. Besides, no formation of aromatic hydrocarbons was observed for a single FeMnK/SiO2 catalyst, and the single HZSM-5 had no activity for directly converting syngas to hydrocarbons. After physical mixing of FeMnK/SiO2 with HZSM-5, the aromatic hydrocarbons were produced, suggesting that the coupling of FeMnK/SiO2 with HZSM-5 promoted the formation of aromatics. Compared to FeMnK/SiO2, the aromatics selectivity of FeMnK/SiO2-HZ27 in C5 + hydrocarbons increased sharply from 0% to 18.82%, whereas the C2-4 olefins selectivity decreased dramatically from 19.09% to 6.86%, and that of C2-4 paraffins selectivity remained unchanged nearly, which implied that light olefins formed on FeMnK/SiO2 could be converted to aromatics in the role of HZSM-5. Therefore, two steps may be existed for syngas to aromatics reaction over the tandem catalysts, as shown in Scheme 1 . The olefins are formed firstly via the FTS reaction over FeMnK/SiO2, and then are converted continually to aromatic hydrocarbons on the HZSM-5 zeolite. Besides, the selectivity of CO2 and CH4 products decreased whereas that of C5 + hydrocarbons increased after physical mixing of FeMnK/SiO2 and HZSM-5, indicating that the integration of FeMnK/SiO2 and HZSM-5 suppressed successfully undesired C1 products and promoted the formation of heavy hydrocarbons. This might be attributed to coupling effect of the tandem reactions, which favored the conversion of intermediates formed. In addition, it could be found that adjusting the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of HZSM-5 changed product distribution of hydrocarbons. Accompanied with the gradual decrease in SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of HZSM-5, the ratio of C2-4 = to C2-4 00 decreased whereas the selectivity of aromatics increased. The aromatics selectivity in C5 + hydrocarbons increased from 13.08% over FeMnK/SiO2-HZ80 to 18.82% over FeMnK/SiO2-HZ27, while the ratio of C2-4 = to C2-4 00 decreased from 1.26 to 0.54 (Table 2). This indicated that a decrease in SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of HZSM-5 facilitated the conversion of light olefins to aromatics. The HZSM-5 zeolite is used widely to converting methanol or olefins to aromatics. The acidity and porosity properties of HZSM-5 as well as reaction conditions play an important role in improving the STA catalytic performances. [16,37,38] It is accepted that the relatively strong acid sites are necessary for methanol converting to aromatics. The results of Cheng et al. [12] indicated that the decrease in Si/Al ratio of HZSM-5 improved obviously the amounts of strong Brönsted acid sites, which were responsible for the formation of aromatic hydrocarbons. However, excessive amounts of strong Brönsted acid sites decreased the selectivity toward aromatics via cracking reaction of long-chain hydrocarbons. In the present work, the strength of strong acid sites increased with decreasing SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of HZSM-5 according to the results of NH3-TPD. Besides, the Py-IR results indicated that a decrease in SiO2/Al2O3 ratio improved the amounts of Brönsted acid sites. The B/L ratio increased from 0.05 to 7.06 as the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio decreased from 80 to 27. On the other hand, the selectivity of aromatics in C5 + hydrocarbons increased from 13.08% to 18.82% whereas that of C2-4 olefins decreased from 11.20% to 6.86% as the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio decreased from 80 to 27. All of these results suggested that the Brönsted acid sites were favorable for the formation of aromatics. [15] In the region of SiO2/Al2O3 ratio from 27 to 80, a linear relationship was presented for the B/L ratio and aromatics selectivity (Fig. 7B), indicating that no excessive amounts of strong Brönsted acid sites existed suppressed the STA reaction. 3.4 Reaction conditions effect The catalytic conversion of syngas to aromatics is strongly dependent on reaction conditions. [16] In this study, the influences of reaction temperature, GHSV and reaction pressure on the performances of the tandem catalyst (FeMnK/SiO2-HZ27) were studied. The effect of reaction temperature on the catalytic performance of FeMnK/SiO2-HZ27 at 2.0 MPa, 6000 h−1 and TOS = 10 h was shown in Fig. 8 . CO conversion increased from 29.65% to 78.35% with the increasing of reaction temperature from 280 °C to 320 °C, and then remained the stable state with continual increasing of temperature (Fig. 8A), which is consistent with the results of Dagle et al. [39]. The selectivity of C5 + hydrocarbons decreased from 65.35% to 40.20% with the increase of temperature, whereas that of CH4 increased from 11.14% to 31.09% (Fig. 8A), respectively, which might be attributed to the enhancement of cracking ability of HZSM-5 zeolite in higher reaction temperature, converting C5 + hydrocarbons into light paraffins. [40] For liquid hydrocarbons, the aromatics selectivity presented an increasing trend with an increase in reaction temperature (Fig. 8B), implying that higher reaction temperature facilitated the formation of aromatic hydrocarbons. This is possible that a decrease in light olefins at higher temperature improved the formation of aromatics via olefins dehydrogenation reaction. [16] The influence of GHSV on the catalytic performance of FeMnK/SiO2-HZ27 at 320 °C, 2.0 MPa and TOS = 10 h was shown in Fig. 9 . The increase of GHSV had no obvious effect on CO conversion, which remained unchanged nearly in the region of 2000 h−1 to 6000 h−1. The selectivity of C2-4 paraffins decreased from 43.65% to 24.13% with increasing GHSV from 2000 h−1 to 6000 h−1, while the selectivities of C2-4 olefins and C5 + hydrocarbons increased from 0.59% and 30.92% to 6.64% and 42.84%, respectively (Fig. 9A). The increased GHSV shortened the contact time of reactants with the acid sites on the tandem catalyst, which suppressed the cracking of C5 + hydrocarbons (reaction (2), as shown in Scheme 1), the oligomerization and cyclization of C2-4 olefins (reaction (1), (3) and (4)). Therefore, the selectivities of C5 + hydrocarbons and C2-4 = increased, while that of C2-4 00 decreased. In the C5 + hydrocarbons, the aromatics selectivity decreased from 68.53% to 23.44% as the GHSV increased from 2000 h−1 to 6000 h−1, indicating that the increase of GHSV suppressed obviously the formation of aromatics. The influence of reaction pressure on the catalytic performance of FeMnK/SiO2-HZ27 at 320 °C, 4000 h−1 and TOS = 10 h was shown in Fig. 10 . The CO conversion increased from 50.78% to 91.05% with increasing pressure from 1.0 MPa to 4.0 MPa (Fig. 10A), indicating that the increase of pressure promoted the catalytic activity of the tandem catalyst. The selectivity of C5 + hydrocarbons increased while that of C2-4 paraffins decreased with an increase in reaction pressure (Fig. 10A), suggesting that higher reaction pressure was in favor for the formation of heavy hydrocarbons. Reaction pressure has an obvious effect on the selectivity of aromatics. From Fig. 10B it could be found that the aromatics selectivity in C5 + hydrocarbons decreased from 62.64% to 31.55% as reaction pressure increased from 1.0 MPa to 4.0 MPa, which indicated that a decrease in reaction pressure was beneficial to the STA reaction. However, an excessive lower pressure suppressed sharply the catalytic activity of the tandem catalyst. Therefore, a suitable reaction pressure (2.0 MPa in the work) could optimize the STA performance. According to the results of reaction conditions effect (reaction temperature, pressure and GHSV), an optimized STA performance was obtained for FeMnK/SiO2-HZ27, which presented 83.80% CO conversion with 57.17% aromatics selectivity in C5 + hydrocarbons at 320 °C, 2.0 MPa and 4000 h−1. 3.5 Effect of the proximity of the two catalysts The hydrocarbon distribution was also affected by the integration manner of the two catalysts (Fig. 11 A). Using a dual-bed configuration with FeMnK/SiO2 packed above the HZSM-5 zeolite and separated by a layer of quartz wool, the CH4 selectivity was relative low (10.65%), whereas the selectivity of aromatics was only 22.97%. By moving the two catalysts into a closer proximity (from dual-bed to granule-mixing and then to powder-mixing), the aromatics selectivity enhanced and the C5 +’ (C5 + hydrocarbons except for aromatics) selectivity reduced. The aromatics selectivity reached 29.04% over powder-mixing. The closer proximity of the two catalysts enables faster transfer of olefins intermediates formed on FeMnK/SiO2 to HZSM-5 zeolite, favoring the selective formation of aromatics. Fig. 11B showed the products distribution over powder-mixing, indicating that the higher olefins were almost converted and the liquid hydrocarbons (C5 +) were mainly composed of aromatics. The stability of the FeMnK/SiO2-HZ27 catalyst with powder-mixing was shown in Fig. 11C. CO conversion remained stable during reaction while the aromatics selectivity decreased gradually, indicating that the HZSM-5 zeolite deactivated gradually with time on stream. This might be attributed to the blocking of aromatics product inside microporous structures of HZSM-5, and the formation of carbon deposition on the catalyst surface, decreasing the catalytic activity of HZSM-5. The optimization of catalytic stability over the tandem catalyst will be studied in the future. 4 Conclusions The coupling of FeMnK/SiO2 with HZSM-5 had significant influences on the STA performances. Physical mixing of FeMnK/SiO2 with HZSM-5 did not changed pore structures of single catalyst. The decrease in SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of HZSM-5 resulted in the decrease of morphology and crystal sizes, which restrained the reduction of iron oxides in the tandem catalyst. Especially, the amounts of strong Brönsted acid sites increased gradually accompanied with decreasing SiO2/Al2O3 ratio in HZSM-5. The single FeMnK/SiO2 catalyst presented a typical FTS performance without the formation of aromatics, whereas HZSM-5 had no activity for converting syngas. The combination of FeMnK/SiO2 and HZSM-5 promoted obviously the formation of aromatics in consumption of light olefins intermediates. A linear relationship between the B/L ratio and aromatics selectivity was displayed, suggesting that the strong Brönsted acid sites played an important role in improving the STA reaction. An increase in both the GHSV and pressure resulted in the decrease of the aromatics selectivity, while an increase in reaction temperature was in favor for the formation of aromatic hydrocarbons. Besides, a closer proximity of the two catalysts favored the selective formation of aromatics. By optimizing the acid sites and reaction conditions of the tandem catalysts, 83.80% of CO conversion with 57.17% of aromatics selectivity were obtained for FeMnK/SiO2-HZ27 at 320 °C, 2.0 MPa and 4000 h−1. coredata.dc:description: Direct synthesis of aromatics from syngas was studied by a tandem catalyst of FeMnK/SiO2 with HZSM-5. A decrease in SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of HZSM-5 decreased the crystal sizes of the tandem catalyst, restraining the reduction of iron oxides. Especially, The HZSM-5 with lower SiO2/Al2O3 ratio promoted the formation of strong Brönsted acid sites (BAS). There existed a linear relationship between the BAS amount and aromatics selectivity. Increasing reaction temperature facilitated the formation of aromatics while the increase in both gas space velocity (GHSV) and pressure restrained the selectivity of aromatics. The tandem catalyst of FeMnK/SiO2 with HZSM-5 presented excellent STA performances of 83.80% CO conversion and 57.17% aromatics selectivity under optimizing reaction conditions of 320 °C, 2.0 MPa and 4000 h−1. This work indicated that a combination of Fe-Mn based catalyst with HZSM-5 could promote the direct conversion of syngas to aromatic hydrocarbons.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of aromatics from syngas over FeMnK/SiO2 and HZSM-5 tandem catalysts
